events.text:
DATE: OCTOBER 1936
LOCATION: LOS ANGELES, CALIFORNIA, UNITED STATES OF AMERICA
The journey was long and arduous. There were times you had to go hungry so Soot could eat, but eventually you make it to Los Angeles.

You wander the streets of Los Angeles, marveling at how different it feels from home. 
The streets are wider, the way people talk and walk and live is so different from home. 
It feels better here, but you can’t help but feel alone.
[i]Meow.[/i]
You hug Soot.
[i]Mrowwwww.[/i]

She must be hungry.
Your stomach growls too. You feel slightly dizzy from hunger and thirst.

events.question: You pull out your last piece of bread. It definitely looks suspicious–is that mold on its edge?

events.choice: Feed her your last piece of bread.

events.text: Here you go Soot.
You rip off the moldy spot and toss it away, then let Soot lick the good parts off your palm.

events.choice: Wait until you can get better food.

events.text:
This isn’t good bread, anyway. The mold spores could have spread to the seemingly fine sides. You don’t want to risk getting Soot and yourself sick.
You toss it away.

events.choice: Share your last piece of bread.

events.text: You split the bread in half and let Soot lick her piece off your palm.

events.question: You really need to get some decent food and a job soon.

events.text: [i]Meow.[/i]
That’s all the food we have left, Soot. Let’s get going.

You begin to look for work. You can’t live off scraps forever.
You pop your head into different stores and restaurants, asking if they need a helping hand.
No one’s hiring. Makes sense, considering the unemployment rate nowadays.
You find an alleyway and start digging through the trash.

events.question: What luck! You find a half-eaten hamburger!

events.text: Soot sniffs it and turns her head away.
Yeah… it doesn’t look that great to me either.

You take a bite of the intact parts. 
It’s surprisingly good!
Soot sniffs it and turns her head away.
It’s all mine, then, Soot~

You take a bite of the intact parts.
It’s surprisingly good!
[i]Mrow.[/i]
She paws for it.
Oh, [i]now[/i] you want it. Very well.
The two of you eat it together.

You grab a piece of cardboard and write “HOMELESS PLEASE HELP,” then sit on the sidewalk and wait.
As people pass you on the street, you say:
Please, help me. I’m homeless. I don’t have any food.

Some of them drop a coin into your hat. Most don’t.
After a few hours, you still don’t have enough for a meal.
You realize begging won’t help your situation.

As you wander the streets of Los Angeles, you pass a university campus with large, towering brick buildings. 
University, huh? You are around the age that most attend, but it wasn’t like you have the money to go. And what would you study anyways?
On the walls surrounding the university, you see a job opportunity posted on a flyer:
HIRING ACADEMIC ASSISTANT. WILL ORGANIZE PAPERS AND GRAB BOOKS FROM THE TOPS OF SHELVES. AND DE-CLUTTER. AND CARRY HEAVY BOXES OF [b]PRECIOUS RESEARCH[/b]! CONTACT: HOWARD ALLWRIGHT, PHD.
Below is his contact info and address. Apparently, an interview is required, but not a resume.
[i]Meow.[/i]
Exactly. I think this is a job opportunity I can’t let slip by! Let’s go.

This is a job opportunity you can’t let slip by you! 
You head to the address.

It requires you to enter the campus of this university, which you read as the University of California, Los Angeles.
And… you quickly become lost. The place feels like an utter maze.

You try to ask for help from anyone, but everyone rushes past you, heads down. Some of them grimace at you, as if you were a disgusting creature.
Oh.
You had been traveling for weeks without a single shower. That made sense.

Eventually, you find the Anthropology building and enter it, looking at the directory for Professor Howard Allwright’s office. 
It’s three floors up, and after climbing the stairs you make it to the door.
You take in a breath and knock on the door, underneath a sign reading “Professor Howard Allwright - Anthropology.”
[i]CRASH![/i]
The door slams open.
HELLO!
Uh, hi.
The Professor adjusts his glasses.
Are you here to apply to be my assistant?
Yes, sir.
Oh, no, no–sirs aren’t needed! Come in, come in.
The Professor ushers you into his office. It’s cluttered and very dusty.
Sit, sit.
You sit on the couch with Soot.

events.question: So, I have a few interview questions for you, my boy. What’s your name?

events.text: [YOUR NAME]. And this is Soot.
[i]Chirp[/i].
A pleasure to meet you, [YOUR NAME] and Soot! I am Professor Howard Allwright.
Definitely not [YOUR NAME]. And this is Soot.
[i]Chirp[/i].
Very well, Definitely Not [YOUR NAME] and Soot! It’s a pleasure to meet you! I am Professor Howard Allwright.
No, no, I was joking! My name is [YOUR NAME].
The Professor scratches his head.
Oh.

events.question: Alright, next question. Have you heard the story of [i]Journey to the West[/i]?

events.text: Excellent!
What?! It’s a classic in Buddhist literature!
The Professor starts to tell you the entire story…

[i]In the Journey to the West, the monk Tripitaka journeys to deliver the sutras from the Buddha himself to the West. Tripitaka has the aid of four other companions: Sun Wukong, the mischievous Monkey King possessing immense combat strength. [/i]

[i]Sandy, the serious-headed companion with a straight face. Pigsy, the one who looks like a Pig, who often causes trouble. And finally, the reliable White Dragon Horse. On their journey, they encounter various perils in the form of demons…[/i]
It was… a lot of information.

events.question: Alright, next question. Do you believe in magic?

events.text: Understandable, understandable.

He pulls out an amulet from his pocket and shows it to you. 
It looks ancient, like something that wouldn’t originate in Los Angeles, let alone the United States, at all.

This amulet is [i]magical[/i]. I am [i]convinced[/i] it’s connected to the [i]Journey to the West[/i]! My colleague, Raj, found this nearby the sacred valleys of Tibet! 
There must be some treasure hidden within this priceless artifact. It’s the discovery of a lifetime.
If I can even [i]open[/i] it.

The Professor tries to pry open the amulet’s center, to no avail.
He sighs.
Everyone thinks my research is crazy, and all the youngsters are busy going out and about nowadays. No one’s interested in good old anthropological research!
So, I offer you the job! An office assistant to help me clean up–
He gestures at all the paraphernalia lying haphazardly around the office. There’s barely any room to walk, and it’s very dusty.

And to reach the high shelves without me having to break my back, and to carry my boxes! That would be swell! 
I love my research, but I’m just not as full of vigor as before!
The Professor audibly cracks his back.

What do you say, [YOUR NAME]? How about becoming my assistant? You can live in my office! I know many are struggling with housing nowadays.
Of course, if you have any questions–I’ll be happy to answer them!

events.question: That was indeed a lot of information, all at once.

events.choice: “What are the sacred valleys of Tibet?”

events.text:
Ah, they are also known as beyuls! Within the hills and valleys of Tibet are sacred, magical lands called [i]beyuls[/i], watched over by Buddhist deities.
These beyuls are considered places of paradise… and fictional by most people.

events.question: But I know they exist! Beyuls are my life’s work.

events.text: Ah, Raj Ghoshal! He is my young colleague from the University of Calcutta. He’s the only person who’s research is related to my own!

events.question: In fact, I believe he is around your age, [YOUR NAME]. Raj is quite the prodigy!

events.choice: “Why is your amulet connected to Journey to the West?”

events.text: All of my years of research points to the tale. If you want, I can lay it all out for you!
Oh no. He’s going to info-dump again!
Oh, I think I’m alright without knowing!
The Professor frowns.
Are you sure? No [i]student[/i] ever asks about my research. I’d be happy to share it with you!
How about another time?
Of course! Ask about it anytime, [YOUR NAME].

events.choice: “Why is your amulet connected to Journey to the West?”

events.text: All of my years of research points to the tale. If you want, I can lay it all out for you!
Oh no. He’s going to info-dump again!
Oh, I think I’m alright without knowing!
The Professor frowns.
Are you sure? No [i]student[/i] ever asks about my research. I’d be happy to share it with you!
How about another time?

In fact, I believe he is around your age, [YOUR NAME]. Raj is quite the prodigy!

In fact, I believe he is around your age, [YOUR NAME]. Raj is quite the prodigy!
Ah, Raj Ghoshal! He is my young colleague from the University of Calcutta. He’s the only person who’s research is related to my own!

events.question: In fact, I believe he is around your age, [YOUR NAME]. Raj is quite the prodigy!

events.choice: “What are the sacred valleys of Tibet?”

events.text:
Ah, they are also known as beyuls! Within the hills and valleys of Tibet are sacred, magical lands called [i]beyuls[/i], watched over by Buddhist deities.
These beyuls are considered places of paradise… and fictional by most people.
But I know they exist! Beyuls are my life’s work.
The Professor clears his throat.
Uh, let me be honest with you, [YOUR NAME].
I've posted job advertisements for a couple months already. Whenever I interview someone and offer them the job, they decline. I can’t imagine why.

You understand. The Professor is quite the personality and… he has an interest in magic? 
His research project almost sounds delusional.

events.question: Just know that I fully understand if you want to decline this offer.

events.text:
You need a job anyway, and even though the Professor has a few screws loose, he seems like an honest individual.
You had no home to go back to anyway. And besides… magic? This was kind of interesting.
Take your time, [YOUR NAME].
[i]Meow.[/i]

Magic, Journey to the West, and beyuls, huh? They are certainly interesting topics.
You think about any other job you could potentially get.
Flipping burgers.
Cleaning dishes.
Serving customers.
Wait–why do you envision yourself with food?!
[i]Hrrrr.[/i]

Right, you must be hungry.
Your stomach growls just to prove its point.
Are you hungry, [YOUR NAME]? Here, you can have my sandwich–and I’ll go steal some tuna from the staff room for your cat.
No worries, I’m not hungry.
I can tell when a boy is starved! Eat, I’ll be back.

The Professor leaves the room.
Now alone, you start eating the sandwich. Before you know it, you’ve shoveled it down your throat. 
The Professor returns with a can of tuna for Soot.
[i]Purrrrrr.[/i]
You’re very welcome, Soot!

He pets her.
The Professor is kind. You wonder if you can ever find an employer as kind as him.
You: I accept.
Sorry, Professor. I appreciate it, but I want to try other career paths.
The Professor nods, even though he is a little disappointed.
I understand, [YOUR NAME]! Best of luck with your pursuits! Here, take this box of cookies before you leave!!!

And off you went in the streets of Los Angeles. You work multiple small jobs.
Still, you can’t help but feel like there’s more to life than a job washing dishes.
Excellent!

For the next few months, you work under the Professor. You tidy up his office and carry his heavy boxes of paper and research items.
The months glide by, until a certain colleague from India arrives to visit the Professor…
